entity: Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
entity_raw_name: I.	Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

27.I.1	The mandate is derived from the priorities established in relevant General Assembly resolutions and decisions, including resolution 46/182, in which the Assembly set out the guiding principles of humanitarian response and affirmed the leadership role of the Secretary-General to ensure better preparation and effective response to natural disasters and complex emergencies. This mandate has been confirmed and consolidated through the normative developments of various resolutions over the past 33 years. The Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs is responsible for ensuring the timely, coherent, coordinated and principled response of the international community to natural disasters and complex emergencies and for facilitating the transition from emergency relief to rehabilitation and sustainable development. With over 305 million people in need of humanitarian assistance in 2025 and extreme poverty and hunger on the rise, owing to the compounded effects of emerging and prolonged armed conflicts and the crisis of climate change, ensuring well-coordinated and principled humanitarian assistance by the international community remains as important as ever.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

27.I.2	The year 2024 was one of the most challenging in recent history for civilians caught in conflicts. By mid-2024, nearly 123 million people had been forcibly displaced by conflict and violence, marking the twelfth consecutive annual increase. Armed conflicts continued to take a heavy toll on civilians, and the crisis of climate change exacerbated humanitarian needs. The global food security crisis affected over 280 million people daily as acute hunger spread and intensified.

27.I.3	In the face of these challenges, the Office will continue to enhance the coordination of effective and efficient delivery of humanitarian assistance, together with humanitarian organizations. The Office will continue to develop and promote a common policy on humanitarian issues for the United Nations system and its partners; coordinate response to humanitarian emergencies; mobilize United Nations capacity to expedite the provision of humanitarian assistance; and strengthen anticipatory approaches and early warning early action systems, with special attention paid to those in the most vulnerable situations. In addition, the Office will advocate and contribute to better preparedness for more timely humanitarian assistance in emergencies; advocate on humanitarian issues; and strengthen the analysis and availability of timely information on emergencies and natural disasters, in accordance with its mandate. The Office will also support the mobilization of resources for countries and communities facing humanitarian emergencies, including host communities, by scaling up timely and predictable funding, advancing innovative and anticipatory financing mechanisms and strengthening partnerships with international financial institutions to prevent, reduce and respond to humanitarian suffering. Furthermore, the Office will continue to advocate for safe and unhindered humanitarian access, the safety and security of humanitarian personnel, and respect for international humanitarian law.

27.I.4	With regard to cooperation with other entities at the global, regional, national and local levels, the Office will continue to work with national and local governments, affected communities and other stakeholders, including regional disaster management and response organizations, other regional and subregional organizations, private sector actors and first responders, to promote principled, timely and effective humanitarian responses.

27.I.5	With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Office will continue, through the Inter-Agency Standing Committee and its subsidiary bodies, to coordinate the development of guidance for the humanitarian system, including on operations policy development and advocacy and supporting implementation of the Secretary-General’s Action Agenda on Internal Displacement. The Office will provide and manage global platforms, such as the United Nations Disaster Assessment and Coordination Team mechanism and the International Search and Rescue Advisory Group, to pool resources and facilitate a coordinated response to humanitarian crises. The Office will also collaborate closely with United Nations agencies, funds and programmes, at both the Headquarters and country levels throughout the humanitarian programme cycle, to streamline the current guidance and indicators associated with thematic humanitarian issues. This will enable effective and consistent system-wide response strategies that meet the humanitarian needs of people in vulnerable situations and minimize duplication and gaps in response efforts. The Office’s country, regional and liaison offices are strategically located to work with governments and assist in humanitarian preparedness and response.
27.I.6	With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Natural disasters will continue to increase in frequency and magnitude, owing, among other things, to the adverse effects of the crisis of climate change;
(b)	The impact of the global economic contraction, compounded by the impacts of natural disasters and armed conflicts, will continue to be felt and will increase the vulnerability of people;
(c)	Humanitarian needs and funding requirements will remain high.

27.I.7	The Office integrates a gender perspective into its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, including through gender analysis, prevention, response and mitigation of gender-based violence, and by promoting the participation and leadership of women in decision-making.

27.I.8	The Office advances United Nations system-wide commitments on protection from sexual exploitation and abuse and sexual harassment. The Under-Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Emergency Relief Coordinator, as Chair of the Inter-Agency Standing Committee, leads and promotes Committee efforts that are aimed at ensuring that people caught up in crises feel safe and respected and can gain access to the protection and assistance that they need. The Office will promote system-wide commitments to ensure that the affected population and personnel engaged in the delivery of humanitarian assistance are protected from sexual harassment and abuse.

27.I.9	In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Office will work to make humanitarian programming and responses more inclusive of persons with disabilities, in particular by ensuring that their needs are reflected in humanitarian data. On the basis of gaps identified through the previous implementation of the Strategy, the Office will develop an action plan outlining the institutional and operational changes necessary to ensure disability inclusion.
Legislative mandates
27.I.10	The list below, which was reviewed in the preparation of the proposed programme budget, provides all mandates entrusted to the programme.

children.text: Evaluation activities
27.I.12	The following evaluations conducted by the Office and completed in 2024 have guided the proposed programme plan for 2026:
(a)	Inter-agency humanitarian evaluation of the response to the humanitarian crisis in northern Ethiopia;
(b)	Inter-agency humanitarian evaluation of the response to the humanitarian crisis in Afghanistan.

27.I.13	In response to the results of the evaluations referenced above, the Office will support humanitarian coordinators in improving coordination structures, operational readiness and the integration of basic services into humanitarian responses.
27.I.14	The following evaluations to be conducted by the Office are planned for 2026:
(a)	Evaluation of an area of strategic importance linked to the Office’s strategic priorities outlined in the strategic plan for the period 2023–2026;
(b)	Inter-agency joint evaluation of humanitarian system-wide scale-up activations.
Programme of work
Subprogramme 1 – Policy and analysis
Objective
27.I.15	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to improve the strategic and operational coherence of humanitarian response.
Strategy
27.I.16	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Identify emerging humanitarian trends to support the comprehensive, authoritative and evidence-based assessment of global humanitarian needs and analyse challenges and opportunities for humanitarian policy and programme development;

(b)	Identify policy and programmatic solutions, best practices and lessons learned to be applied in the humanitarian field and take steps to increase preparedness and operational readiness to respond to humanitarian priorities and reduce humanitarian needs.
27.I.17	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Humanitarian assistance that addresses evolving challenges and reduces the gap between humanitarian needs and response capacity;
(b)	A humanitarian system that remains relevant and adapts to the ever-changing operational environment;
(c)	Humanitarian actors applying innovative solutions in humanitarian operations.
Programme performance in 2024
Humanitarian practitioners identified pathways for strengthening humanitarian assistance

27.I.18	In December 2024, the subprogramme, in collaboration with the United Nations Foundation, convened the thirteenth annual Global Humanitarian Policy Forum, bringing together leaders and practitioners to reflect on the state of the global humanitarian landscape. Through a series of virtual interactive sessions, participants discussed the most pressing challenges facing humanitarian assistance efforts and explored new pathways to enhance the system’s ability to adapt to change and respond. The theme of the 2024 Policy Forum underscored the urgent need to rethink and reshape humanitarian strategies in response to increasingly complex challenges and escalating levels of humanitarian need. It concluded with the development of actionable recommendations for humanitarian agencies, donors and partners, including to further promote community-driven approaches to humanitarian action, scale up climate action, depoliticize humanitarian assistance and foster strategic, inclusive leadership.
27.I.19	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 27.I.2).
Table 27.I.2
Performance measure

table_content.text: Humanitarian practitioners identified actionable recommendations to strengthen humanitarian response

children.text: Result 2: increased engagement of communities in humanitarian response to effectively address their needs

27.I.22	The subprogramme’s work contributed to the adoption of improved active listening approaches in four pilot countries, which met the planned target. For example, in the Philippines, community engagement resulted in communities identifying the need to safely store livelihood assets, such as sewing machines and fishing boats, prior to a storm to ensure that valuable equipment is preserved, allowing people to quickly resume their livelihoods after a storm.

children.text: Result 3: improved collective learning through the integration of local perspectives – Proposed programme plan for 2026
27.I.24	Humanitarian efforts are most effective when they are driven by the needs and priorities of affected communities.
Lessons learned and planned change

27.I.25	The lesson for the subprogramme was that, by understanding the priorities, capacities, risks and vulnerabilities of communities and collaborating with other sectors, humanitarians can more effectively address the urgent needs of affected communities, enhance their resilience and reduce the long-term need for humanitarian assistance. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will ensure that learning events prioritize the participation and insights of local and national actors, allowing their perspectives to shape recommendations and system-wide practices.
27.I.26	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 27.I.5).
Table 27.I.5
Performance measure

children.text: Subprogramme 2 – Coordination of humanitarian action and emergency response
Objective

27.I.28	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to ensure a coherent, effective and timely humanitarian response to reduce and alleviate human suffering in natural disasters and complex emergencies.
Strategy
27.I.29	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Maintain an effective coordination system to convene humanitarian actors and support senior humanitarian leadership at the global level and in countries affected by natural disasters and complex emergencies, by coordinating timely and objective multisectoral assessments and analyses of humanitarian needs; supporting response planning; and programming and monitoring the provision of assistance to people in need during and in the aftermath of emergencies;

(b)	Promote the delivery of principled humanitarian assistance and coordinate resource mobilization efforts to reduce funding gaps that hamper humanitarian operations, including through effective partnerships with humanitarian actors, Member States, regional organizations and civil society, and the effective management and disbursement of funding from humanitarian pooled funds;

(c)	Increase the use of anticipatory approaches and early warning early action systems to prevent and reduce human suffering, especially with regard to disasters relating to the crisis of climate change;

(d)	Strengthen links between humanitarian assistance and efforts to support resilience, early recovery and development to reduce the needs and vulnerabilities of affected people, ensuring that sex-, age- and disability-oriented data are taken into account in all aspects of the response.
27.I.30	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Improved prioritization of humanitarian responses, based on informed and timely decision-making by humanitarian actors;
(b)	Reduced duplication of response interventions and reduced gaps in humanitarian response;
(c)	An adequately funded international humanitarian system, to respond to increasingly frequent natural disasters and complex emergencies.
Programme performance in 2024
Reaching people in need in increasingly challenging contexts

27.I.31	The subprogramme helped humanitarian partners in Member States to organize responses through 24 country humanitarian response plans, 9 regional plans, 10 flash appeals and 6 other forms of appeals, on the basis of a common understanding of the specific humanitarian contexts, which enabled collective and coordinated responses. In 2024, the United Nations and over 2,000 partner organizations reached nearly 116 million people with at least one form of assistance. This was despite the fact that humanitarians and the services they provide came under unprecedented attack in 2024, which was the most dangerous year on record for humanitarian personnel, with 356 humanitarians killed. Local humanitarian personnel, who serve their own communities on the front lines of conflict, are the most exposed to violence. Between January and November 2024, 96 per cent of all humanitarian personnel killed, injured or kidnapped were national or local staff. Despite focused response plans and appeals, funding did not keep pace with requirements in 2024. Just 46 per cent of the amount required according to the Global Humanitarian Overview was received. These shortages have affected crises worldwide.
27.I.32	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 27.I.I).
Figure 27.I.I
Performance measure: number of people receiving at least one form of humanitarian assistance, and number of humanitarian response plans (annual)
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: transforming humanitarian programming to improve the delivery of aid to people in need – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

27.I.33	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 79 per cent of humanitarian country operations reporting simplified, shorter humanitarian programme cycle processes and improved ability to focus on the delivery of humanitarian assistance, which exceeded the planned target of 75 per cent.
27.I.34	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 27.I.7).
Table 27.I.7
Performance measure

children.text: Result 2: increased participation of local and national actors in humanitarian coordination mechanisms – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

27.I.35	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 93 per cent of countries with local and national actors participating in humanitarian coordination mechanisms, which exceeded the planned target of 85 per cent.
27.I.36	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 27.I.II).
Figure 27.I.II
Performance measure: countries with local and national actors participating in humanitarian coordination mechanismsa (annual)
(Percentage)
a	Data for 2024 are based on most recent data collected through the annual coordination survey.
Result 3: scaled up anticipatory approaches and early warning early action systems – Proposed programme plan for 2026

27.I.37	Anticipatory approaches and early warning early action systems are focused on action before predictable disasters strike, with a view to preventing and reducing human suffering and assisting those in need. In its resolution 79/140, the General Assembly encouraged the United Nations and humanitarian organizations to continue to scale up anticipatory approaches and early warning early action systems and encouraged exploring, developing and, where appropriate, strengthening innovative and anticipatory mechanisms and approaches, such as forecast-based financing and disaster risk insurance, to reduce the impact of disasters and address humanitarian needs.
Lessons learned and planned change

27.I.38	The lesson for the subprogramme, based on pilot projects, was that anticipatory approaches and early warning early action systems are effective in preventing and reducing human suffering and economic losses. The subprogramme is using predictive data to take action before disasters strike, through the establishment of pre-agreed anticipatory action frameworks under which predefined humanitarian interventions are triggered when specific forecasts indicate a high likelihood of a shock. This allows for a faster and more effective response by releasing pre-arranged funding, with a view to mitigating the impact before the crisis fully unfolds. Further scaling up of anticipatory approaches and early warning early action systems is needed, including through the consistent use of anticipatory financing mechanisms to ensure timely and predictable funding. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will scale up anticipatory approaches and early warning early action systems to cover more countries and hazards, including through increased financing by humanitarian pooled funds for the coordination of such approaches.
27.I.39	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 27.I.III).
Figure 27.I.III
Performance measure: number of countries with increased use of anticipatory approaches and early warning early action systems (annual)

children.text: Subprogramme 3 – Emergency support services
Objective
27.I.41	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to expedite international humanitarian assistance to victims of emergencies and natural disasters.
Strategy
27.I.42	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:

(a)	Provide effective and well-coordinated operational response support to disaster-affected States and continue to coordinate and support humanitarian actors to prepare for, plan, deliver and monitor the humanitarian response through the humanitarian programme cycle;

(b)	Strengthen the capacities of Member State mechanisms for emergency response through the management of various technical response services, including the United Nations Disaster Assessment and Coordination Team mechanism, the International Search and Rescue Advisory Group system, the environmental emergency response mechanism of the Joint Environment Unit of the United Nations Environment Programme and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, as well as through the provision of training, guidance and technical support, including a continued focus on effective facilitation and functioning of inter-cluster coordination groups and their associated subgroups, and on the role and capacity of local responders;

(c)	Promote collaboration with various partner organizations, including the private sector, through the Connecting Business initiative, which is managed jointly by the Office and the United Nations Development Programme, and United Nations humanitarian civil-military coordination and humanitarian negotiation services; and by continuing to conduct courses and training sessions and meeting regularly with partners through focal points in regional and country offices;

(d)	Standardize and improve operational procedures for international urban search and rescue teams through the International Search and Rescue Advisory Group and activate and coordinate rapid response coordination platforms, such as the virtual On-Site Operations Coordination Centre and the Global Disaster Alert and Response Coordination System, as well as provide near real-time alerts on natural disasters around the world and tools to facilitate response coordination.
27.I.43	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Enhanced response capacity of local, regional and international responders for natural disasters;
(b)	More efficient and timely mobilization and deployment of emergency response services;

(c)	Improved effectiveness and prioritization of preparedness and response of the national emergency management authorities in disaster-prone countries, ensuring that assistance and protection reach the people who need it most;

(d)	More effective operational engagement by humanitarian organizations with both local and international private sectors before, during and after emergencies. This will ensure that private sector contributions are well coordinated and recognized and that humanitarian interventions contribute to longer-term development goals.
Programme performance in 2024
Member States were enabled to provide rapid response to sudden-onset and complex emergencies

27.I.44	In 2024, the subprogramme responded to sudden-onset and complex emergencies and supported emergency preparedness in four countries: Barbados, Grenada, Jamaica and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, through the utilization of United Nations Disaster Assessment and Coordination teams and systems. On 1 July 2024, Hurricane Beryl struck Grenada and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines as a category 4 hurricane, before intensifying to a category 5. The subprogramme promptly deployed staff and United Nations Disaster Assessment and Coordination teams to Barbados and Jamaica. Funding from the Central Emergency Response Fund was also allocated to enable the United Nations and its partners to swiftly deliver life-saving aid. The Joint Environment Unit of the United Nations Environment Programme and the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs deployed two specialists in environmental assessment and coordination within the United Nations Disaster Assessment and Coordination teams. The teams established On-Site Operations Coordination Centres in Carriacou, Grenada, and Union, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, to facilitate a coordinated response. The International Humanitarian Partnership deployed from Barbados to Grenada and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines to support local responders, emergency management authorities, the Caribbean Disaster Emergency Management Agency, as the regional response mechanism, and the private sector. The subprogramme also laid the groundwork for assessing the scale of destruction, damage and humanitarian needs. In collaboration with partners, the subprogramme developed and launched a response plan, amounting to $9 million, to provide immediate humanitarian assistance to 43,000 people. In addition, at the request of the affected Governments for assistance, the Joint Environment Unit responded to environmental emergencies arising from sudden-onset and complex emergencies in such countries as Ethiopia, Seychelles and Yemen.
27.I.45	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 27.I.IV).
Figure 27.I.IV

Performance measure: United Nations Disaster Assessment and Coordination teams mobilized and dispatched to the affected country within 48 hours of receiving a request for international assistance (annual)
(Percentage)
Planned results for 2026
Result 1: engagement of all actors to improve access for the most vulnerable to humanitarian assistance and protection – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

27.I.46	The subprogramme’s work contributed to improved access for the most vulnerable to humanitarian assistance and protection through the provision of support for humanitarian negotiations and diplomacy efforts in six contexts, which met the planned target.
27.I.47	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 27.I.V).
Figure 27.I.V
Performance measure: number of contexts in which interlocutors with influence on humanitarian access engage in diplomacy and negotiations (annual)
Result 2: enhanced partnership with the private sector in collective humanitarian action – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

27.I.48	The subprogramme’s work contributed to the establishment of 20 Connecting Business initiative-supported local private sector networks, which met the planned target. In addition, given that regional bodies are members of 3 of the 20 networks, the Connecting Business initiative is now present in over 70 countries worldwide. The networks collectively responded to 16 humanitarian emergencies in 2024, mobilizing more than $14 million in humanitarian assistance to benefit at least 2.6 million people around the world.
27.I.49	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 27.I.VI).
Figure 27.I.VI
Performance measure: number of Connecting Business initiative-supported local private sector networks that respond to crises (cumulative)
Result 3: crisis-affected people receive emergency humanitarian assistance in the immediate aftermath of a catastrophe – Proposed programme plan for 2026

27.I.50	Climate change is intensifying the severity of weather-related disasters and severely affecting food systems. It has made the impact of events like the devastating Horn of Africa drought (2020 to 2023) much more severe and significantly increased the likelihood of their recurrence. Climate change has also increased the likelihood and destructive power of major hurricanes, such as Hurricane Beryl in 2024, which is the strongest June hurricane ever recorded in the Atlantic.
Lessons learned and planned change

27.I.51	The lesson for the subprogramme was that the increasing severity and frequency of natural disasters necessitate ongoing training and response readiness efforts for sudden-onset emergencies. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will strengthen its capacity to respond to sudden-onset emergencies and enhance coordination for a more efficient and tailored humanitarian response. This will be achieved by enhancing the response readiness efforts of its members and partners throughout the provision of training, deploying rapid response capacities, while working with its national members, operational support partners and regional partners to strengthen local preparedness and response mechanisms.
27.I.52	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 27.I.VII).
Figure 27.I.VII

Performance measure: number of emergency responders trained in United Nations Disaster Assessment and Coordination system and United Nations humanitarian civil-military coordination to deploy and respond to sudden-onset emergencies (annual)
Deliverables

children.text: Subprogramme 4 – Humanitarian emergency information and advocacy
Objective

27.I.54	The objective, to which this subprogramme contributes, is to ensure effective advocacy for humanitarian principles and knowledge-sharing in serving populations affected by disasters and emergencies.
Strategy
27.I.55	To contribute to the objective, the subprogramme will:
(a)	Intensify its efforts to raise public awareness of international humanitarian law through targeted communications, clear and accessible messages and proactive media engagement;
(b)	Produce and improve its analytical information products, including digital products and services.
27.I.56	The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Increased respect for international humanitarian law to enhance the protection of affected people and improve unhindered access to humanitarian assistance;
(b)	Improved humanitarian decisions based on more timely and accurate information on humanitarian crises, including intersectoral analysis of the humanitarian situation and its severity and needs.
Programme performance in 2024
Humanitarian actors provided with more timely support

27.I.57	Since 1996, the subprogramme has managed and curated humanitarian information through the ReliefWeb platform, which has become the most utilized data source for humanitarian analysis. Its editorial team monitors and collects information from more than 4,000 key sources, including humanitarian agencies at the international and local levels, governments, think tanks and research institutions, and the media. Editors select, classify, curate and deliver the content that is most relevant to global humanitarian workers and decision makers 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, enabling them to make informed decisions and to plan effective responses. To further enhance access to critical information, in July 2024, the subprogramme launched a tool powered by artificial intelligence, Ask ReliefWeb, which is designed to improve the user experience by allowing users to ask questions about individual reports through a chatbot-like interface. By providing precise answers sourced exclusively from the selected report, Ask ReliefWeb has served to streamline information retrieval, enabling humanitarian actors to quickly access the insights they need by posing simple, targeted questions. This advancement allows humanitarian actors to act more swiftly and effectively, translating critical data into meaningful action on the ground.
27.I.58	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 27.I.10).
Table 27.I.10
Performance measure

table_content.text: 48,400 reports available on the ReliefWeb platform, providing humanitarian actors with timely, reliable information to support informed decision-making and effective crisis response

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: strengthened advocacy for an adequate response to humanitarian situations – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

27.I.59	The subprogramme’s work contributed to strengthened advocacy for adequate response to humanitarian crises, with $979 million pledged through high-level pledging conferences on Ethiopia and the Central Emergency Response Fund, which met the planned target.
27.I.60	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 27.I.11).

Pledges enable adequate response to humanitarian situations

children.text: Result 2: reliable network and connectivity services for humanitarian responders – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026
27.I.61	The subprogramme’s work contributed to 92 quick-to-deploy kits used by humanitarian responders in crisis-affected locations, which exceeded the planned target of 42.
27.I.62	Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see figure 27.I.VIII).
Figure 27.I.VIII
Performance measure: number of quick-to-deploy kits used by humanitarian responders in crisis-affected locations (cumulative)
Result 3: enhanced access to critical data and information – Proposed programme plan for 2026

27.I.63	Efficient technology solutions and standardization are crucial for achieving a coordinated response to humanitarian emergencies. By consolidating and simplifying data access, humanitarian organizations can improve coordination among teams, partners and stakeholders, reducing delays in response efforts. ReliefWeb, the humanitarian information portal managed by the subprogramme, provides reliable and timely information to enable humanitarian personnel to plan effective responses.
Lessons learned and planned change

27.I.64	The lesson for the subprogramme was that without standardization efforts, reducing data fragmentation and improving overall coordination among humanitarian actors would be challenging. In addition, overlapping information services were found to reduce clarity and add to the workload of stakeholders in humanitarian action. Furthermore, owing to the speed and complexity of humanitarian emergencies, real-time information-sharing among humanitarian actors is increasingly required. In applying the lesson, the subprogramme will consolidate existing information services to create a more coherent information management system. The subprogramme will lead the standardization of platforms used internally and by its partners to ensure interoperability and consistency in data management and reporting. The subprogramme will also implement automated data exchange protocols to facilitate real-time information-sharing among humanitarian actors. This will enhance the accuracy and timeliness of data, reducing manual entry errors and delays, and ultimately improving the responsiveness of humanitarian operations.
27.I.65	Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure 27.I.IX).
Figure 27.I.IX
Performance measure: audience growth on ReliefWeb from Humanitarian Response Plan countries (annual)
(Percentage)
Deliverables
27.I.66	Table 27.I.12 lists all deliverables of the subprogramme.
Table 27.I.12
Subprogramme 4: deliverables for 2026, by category and subcategory

table_content.text: Advocacy: shared public advocacy with humanitarian partners, including a humanitarian advocacy and communications group to strengthen consistency in messaging.

Databases and substantive digital materials: field guides, maps and other reference information for more than 1,000 humanitarian operational partners; and information management, shared data standards for information exchange in the humanitarian community, databases and electronic tools, including the International Search and Rescue Advisory Group urban search and rescue directory and common risk and vulnerability assessment methodologies and tools.
Outreach programmes, special events and information materials: information materials on coordination of humanitarian action; and World Humanitarian Day campaign on protection of humanitarian workers.

External and media relations: daily media updates to United Nations accredited correspondents through the noon briefing in New York and twice-weekly Palais des Nations briefings in Geneva; at least 12 on-the-record and background media briefings for global media outlets and two dozen interviews to advocate assistance for people caught in humanitarian crises, to reach decision-making audiences in donor countries and countries with humanitarian situations; and comprehensive communications for the launch of the Global Humanitarian Overview (annual consolidated appeals), in support of the Central Emergency Response Fund, and of pledging conferences for large humanitarian crises.

Digital platforms and multimedia content: humanitarian community digital platforms, such as ReliefWeb, ReliefWeb Response and Humanitarian Data Exchange; guidance and templates on various reporting products for humanitarian organizations and Member States, including situation reports and humanitarian snapshots; and video, social media and other multimedia content on humanitarian issues, international humanitarian law, international human rights law, humanitarian principles, protection of civilians, specific emergency situations and resource mobilization.

Information and communications technology: global information and communications technology and product support for collaboration services; and information and communications technology for emergency response and business continuity services, business intelligence and data analysis services.

Explanation of variances by factor, component and subprogramme – Overall resource changes
Other changes
27.I.70	As shown in table 27.I.16 (1), resource changes reflect a decrease of $29,700 as follows:

Programme support. The decrease of $29,700 under contractual services reflects the adjustment of standard information and communications technology standard rates for Headquarters personnel and non-field personnel outside of Headquarters for 2026.
Extrabudgetary resources

27.I.71	As reflected in tables 27.I.16 (2) and 27.I.17 (2), extrabudgetary resources (including in-kind contributions) amount to $365,460,300. The resources would complement regular budget resources and would be used mainly to provide for 2,226 posts (36 D-1, 100 P-5, 274 P-4, 319 P-3, 25 P-2, 687 National Professional Officer, 8 General Service (Principal level), 104 General Service (Other level) and 673 Local level) and related non-post resources to perform mainly the functions of coordination and delivery of humanitarian assistance.

27.I.72	The extrabudgetary resources under the present section are subject to the oversight of the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs, which has delegated authority from the Secretary-General.
Executive direction and management

27.I.73	The executive direction and management component of the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs comprises the Office of the Under-Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Emergency Relief Coordinator and the Office of the Assistant Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Deputy Emergency Relief Coordinator. The Office of the Under-Secretary-General oversees the Strategic Communication Branch, the Climate Team and the Internally Displaced Persons Unit.  The Office of the Assistant Secretary-General oversees the Operations and Advocacy Division, the Coordination Division, the Information Management Branch, the Planning and Performance Branch, the Policy Branch, the Executive Office, the Regional, Field and Disaster Response Adviser Offices, the Gender Unit and the Financing and Partnerships Division.
27.I.74	The overall responsibilities of the executive direction and management component include the following:

(a)	Provide overall direction, management and policy guidance to the offices in New York and Geneva and in the field, including leadership in the coordination of the overall response of the international community to disasters and humanitarian emergencies;
(b)	Undertake humanitarian diplomacy with Governments of affected countries, including the facilitation of access to emergency areas for the rapid delivery of humanitarian assistance;
(c)	Provide oversight of the humanitarian coordination leadership in the field, as well as management of the field operations;
(d)	Lead on the humanitarian finances and resource mobilization functions, manage the emergency services on behalf of the United Nations system and coordinate with Member States, donors and partners;

(e)	In the case of the Emergency Relief Coordinator, facilitate the work of the Inter-Agency Standing Committee on policy development and advocacy in the humanitarian sector and oversee the Working Group as chair;

(f)	Act as the main adviser to the Secretary-General on humanitarian issues and cooperate closely with other United Nations offices in the planning and coordination of United Nations humanitarian assistance activities in crisis situations;

(g)	Assist the Coordinator of the Executive Committee on Humanitarian Affairs in providing the overall direction, management and supervision of the offices in New York and Geneva, as well as in supporting Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs coordination in the field;

(h)	Interact with Member States, intergovernmental organizations, non-governmental organizations and operational humanitarian agencies, as well as departments of the Secretariat whose responsibilities encompass peacekeeping, political and economic activities, to facilitate joint responses where applicable;

(i)	Provide strategic advice on issues relating to internally displaced persons and engage with relevant partners to drive the implementation of the Secretary General’s action agenda on internal displacement, including through membership in the Steering Group on Internal Displacement Solutions and co-chairing of the GP2.0 multi-stakeholder global platform on internal displacement;

(j)	Manage and coordinate internal evaluations of the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs and inter-agency evaluations, provide secretariat services and chair the Inter-agency Humanitarian Evaluation steering group and coordinate external oversight to ensure organization compliance with audits and evaluation recommendations;

(k)	Lead the work of the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian on gender equality and response to gender-based violence in humanitarian action, including capacity-building, technical guidance and the integration of gender perspectives throughout the humanitarian programme cycle;
(l)	Promote a fair and equitable environment where all individuals are treated with dignity, through focused programmes for learning, staff growth and welfare;

(m)	Provide guidance on and oversee the strategic planning and prioritization of activities of the offices at Headquarters and in the field, organization risk management, business continuity planning and performance monitoring.

27.I.75	In accordance with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, in particular target 12.6 of the Sustainable Development Goals, in which organizations are encouraged to integrate sustainability information into their reporting cycles, and in compliance with the cross-cutting mandate set out in paragraph 19 of General Assembly resolution 72/219, the Office continues to integrate environmental management practices into its operations. As part of its environmental management system, the Office continues to develop an environment and climate action strategy, a policy and an information and analysis dashboard. Country-level initiatives include waste management processes that promote recycling, reduction in the use of single-use plastics and continuous guidance to countries on conducting environmental impact assessments in humanitarian action and integrating environmental and climate considerations into programming.

27.I.76	In 2026, the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs will systematically measure and report on environmental performance through the implementation of its environmental management system. The Office will continue to map its programmatic and operational environmental impacts, work to reduce adverse environmental impacts and maintain climate neutrality through a variety of initiatives. Such initiatives include increasing its use of videoconference and remote meeting options, consistently reviewing its vehicle fleet to ensure that replacements are made only if required and moving to shared facilities when safe, practical and in line with the humanitarian principles, in order to reduce its environmental footprint.

27.I.77	Information on the timely submission of documentation and advance booking for air travel is reflected in table 27.I.19. Managers are asked to implement preventive and corrective measures. Compliance rates are monitored, and statistics and trends are distributed to managers on a quarterly basis. In 2026, the Office will continue to implement measures to improve the compliance rate for air tickets, including: (a) advance planning and nomination of travellers; (b) onboarding of staff planned in advance with contingencies in place (e.g. advance request for visas); and (c) undertaking communication to staff and managers to raise awareness of the requirement.
Table 27.I.19
Compliance rate
(Percentage)

table_content.text: Air tickets purchased at least two weeks before the commencement of travel

children.text: Figure 27.I.XV
Subprogramme 4: distribution of proposed resources for 2026
(Number of posts/thousands of United States dollars)
Programme support

27.I.83	The programme support component comprises the Executive Office, the Human Resources Section, the Procurement, Asset Management and Logistics Section, the Legal and Travel Units and the Budget and Finance Section.

27.I.84	The main responsibilities of the programme support component include: (a) overseeing the financial, human resources, procurement of goods and services, and general administrative aspects of the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs and providing guidance on administrative matters; (b) supporting senior management in formulating policies and instructions, including financial management, workforce planning and staff rostering; (c) coordinating departmental programme budgets and presentations to legislative bodies; (d) continuing to focus on workforce and succession planning, as well as career and staff development, in line with the human resources strategy and the staff strategy; (e) improving financial monitoring and projections of funding requirements for future budgets, managing and effectively utilizing resources, capturing and sharing field information and ensuring the accurate and timely reporting of financial transactions; and (f) focusing on enhancing the service orientation and client focus of its administrative support.

27.I.85	The proposed regular budget resources for 2026 amount to $1,849,500 and reflect a decrease of $29,700 compared with the approved budget for 2025. The proposed change is explained in paragraph 27.I.70. Additional details on the distribution of the proposed resources for 2026 are reflected in table 27.I.25 and figure 27.I.XVI.
